title: Refried Bean and Cheese Enchiladas Recipe
description: These vegetarian bean enchiladas are a quick and easy Mexican-inspired meal to make on busy weeknights. Add cooked chicken and cilantro if you like.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Mexican Main Dishes Enchilada Recipes Vegetarian Refried Bean and Cheese Enchiladas 4.4 (62) 52 Reviews 9 Photos I grew up making these bean enchiladas with my mom and sisters. They're easy to make and incredibly tempting. You can add chicken or cilantro if you like. I suggest pairing them with Mexican rice. Submitted by hunni662 Updated on November 19, 2024 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 9 9 9 9 Prep Time: 25 mins Cook Time: 40 mins Total Time: 1 hr 5 mins Servings: 6 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 6 servings cooking spray 2 (16 ounce) cans refried beans 2 cups shredded Mexican cheese blend, divided ½ cup chopped onion 12 (6 inch) corn tortillas 2 (10 ounce) cans red enchilada sauce Directions Gather the ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray a 9x13-inch casserole dish with cooking spray. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Mix refried beans, 1 1/2 cups cheese, and onion in a microwave-safe bowl. Microwave on high until cheese is melted, about 1 minute. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Stack three tortillas on a microwave-safe plate; microwave on high until warm, about 30 seconds. Repeat to warm remaining tortillas. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Pour enough enchilada sauce onto a small plate to cover. Quickly dip both sides of one tortilla in sauce. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Spoon bean filling down the middle, then wrap tortilla around filling. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place into the prepared baking dish. Repeat to dip, fill, and roll remining tortillas. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Pour remaining enchilada sauce over filled tortillas and sprinkle with remaining cheese. Cover the dish with aluminum foil. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake in the preheated oven until sauce is bubbling and cheese is melted, 35 and 40 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Recipe Tips You can use flour tortillas instead of corn, and green enchilada sauce instead of red.For a vegetarian version, use refried beans that do not contain lard. I Made It Print 134 home cooks made it! Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Refried Bean and Cheese Enchiladas 01 of 09 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 09 Photo by  Michelle Moore 03/18/2020 I made a vegan version mixing Daiya Cheddar Style Shreds with grated Chao slices. I also used 1 can each of refried beans and black beans. Very yummy! 03 of 09 Photo by  jess 10/08/2018 04 of 09 Photo by  Michele Rodrigues-Sandberg 08/27/2018 05 of 09 Photo by  levinmama 02/26/2018 06 of 09 Photo by  BGP 01/10/2018 07 of 09 Photo by  NurseCarol1974 02/11/2016 Instead of using a microwave, I sautéed the onion and added 3 diced jalapeños. I used one can of refried beans and one can of refried black beans. I added the beans and cheese to the pan with the onions and jalapeños and heated until the cheese melted. After tasting the bean/cheese mixture, I wanted to spice it up a bit. So I added some chili powder, cumin, and hot taco sauce. 08 of 09 Photo by  Paula 04/13/2014 I made these exactly by the recipe for a small group of 14. Everyone seemed to like them, but no one raved over them. I appreciated the directions given for heating 3 corn tortillas in the microwave and then dipping them in the enchilada sauce before filling and rolling up. I've always had problems with corn tortillas breaking, but these rolled up perfectly. 09 of 09 Photo by  Baking Nana 04/12/2014 These rank high for EASY of course you can add meat, but you don't have too. For a fast family dinner these fit the bill. 1 You’ll Also Love Black Bean and Veggie Enchiladas 12 Ratings Vegetarian Enchiladas 18 Ratings Roasted Butternut and Black Bean Enchiladas 8 Ratings Black Bean and Rice Enchiladas 164 Ratings 3-Cheese Enchiladas 61 Ratings Sarah's Creamy Veggie Enchiladas 3 Ratings Vegetarian Spinach and Mushroom Enchiladas 7 Ratings Sweet Potato Enchiladas 208 Ratings Potato and Bean Enchiladas 191 Ratings Cheese Enchiladas 136 Ratings Zucchilattas 124 Ratings Vegan Enchilada Bake 7 Ratings Black Bean and Butternut Squash Enchilada Casserole 7 Ratings Vegetarian Bean Burritos 3 Ratings Meatless Mexican Lasagna Vegetarian Black Bean Enchiladas 171 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family.
